thread.title: Review: The Sherlocks at Albert Hall, Manchester
thread.title_full: Review: The Sherlocks at Albert Hall, Manchester

author: manchestereveningnews.co.uk
title: Review: The Sherlocks at Albert Hall, Manchester
text:
Get What's On   Thank you for subscribing!   
MANCHESTER fans have apparently adopted Yorkshire indie stars The Sherlocks as if they were one of their own - the high flying band of brothers selling out their second big show in the city in only four months. 
Last time it was The Ritz, but now the same astonishing scenes unfold on the bouncing floor and balconies at The Albert Hall on Peter Street, taking things to a new level for one of the most exciting new band in Britain. 
This family band - lead singer-songwriter Kiaran and his brother and drummer Brandon, plus lead guitarist Josh Davidson and his brother and bassist Andy - are only eight nights in to a 35 date marathon tour, but this Manchester show is already like an end of run homecoming. Read More 
The loud chants of Sherlocks’ Army begin long before there's any sign of the band and carry on at any opportunity once they're on stage, too - encouraged by Andy’s bass chords between songs. (Photo: Jack Kirwin Photography) 
Live for the Moment kicks things off, Last Night is raucous, and Brandon’s precision drumming keeping things in check on Escapade. 
New single and old favourite Was It Really Worth It? - currently riding high on Radio One and BBC 6 Music - is now an even bigger song, its evocative first five chords, spine tingling chorus, and awesome lyrics make it a fearless and timeless tune. Read More 
New numbers Candle Light and Nobody Knows, plus the big sound and intricate guitar work on the haunting Will You Be There?, have everyone bouncing. The band even surprise fans by playing a fully reworked, country vibe version of Motions. (Photo: Jack Kirwin Photography) 
Blue, with Josh and Andy on soaring backing vocals, and long-time anthem Chasing Shadows wrap things up alongside a huge confetti drop and stunning illuminations by lighting supremo Craig Greenhalgh. 
Against convention, The Sherlocks are a roots up band who have grafted for years to earn a night like this. Here was a people's band at a people's venue. These indie insurgents already have fans that could last a lifetime; this gig won them for ever more. Like us on Facebook
